newsitem.title: USA: US blue chips end lower as interest rates spike up.
newsitem.headline: US blue chips end lower as interest rates spike up.

text.p: Wall Street stocks finished mostly lower on Friday, as investors were twice startled by sharp upturns in U.S. payrolls and manufacturing activity.
While the economic news sparked a sharp sell-off in the bond market, stocks again proved their resilience, shaking off most of an early session decline to end with moderate losses.
By the end, the session appeared to represent little more than a breather for the stock market, with the Dow industrials falling 29 points to 8194.

The late recovery all but erased an early sell-off that dragged the Dow down as many as 119 points, but even so, analysts pointed to the heavy early losses as evidence the market is ill-prepared to withstand any unpleasant surprises.
The surprises today came in the form of a free-fall in the bond market after learning the U.S. economy added 316,000 new jobs in July, far outpacing forecasts for roughly 200,000.
A second report showed U.S. manufacturing activity and prices paid by manufacturers both registered unexpectedly sharp rises, reawakening latent inflation concerns.
Investors immediately engaged in a broad selling spree after the news, intent on cashing in on some of the market's dizzying and relentless gains.

"The image I use is that of a forest that hasn't experienced a fire in a very long time," said Charlie Crane, chief market strategist at Key Asset Management. "You get one spark and suddenly you have a blaze on your hands."
Analysts were reluctant to predict whether the market was destined to duplicate last summer's performance, when stocks corrected steeply after a similar employment report surprise.
But several analysts said the market appeared to have little room to maneuver higher, if only because investors have already built an ideal outlook into pricing levels.
"Both the bond and stock markets have come a very long way," said Gail Dudack, chief investment strategist at UBS Securities.
"What today says is that both markets are in the process of discounting perfection and when you do get a blemish, the result is a sharp retracement," she said.
The retracement hit interest rate sensitive shares particularly hard and sent bank stocks tumbling.
Bank of New York Co Inc fell 1-7/16 to 47-3/16 and BankAmerica Corp shed 1-3/8 to 74-1/8. Dow component J.P. Morgan & Co Inc fell 1-3/8 to 114-1/2.

Among individual issues, Kellogg Co jumped 5-9/16 to 97-7/16 after the company's second quarter earnings more than doubled, coming in well ahead of Wall Street estimates. The company also raised its dividend and declared a stock split.

Kenneth Cole Productions Inc fell 2-3/4 to 12-1/2 after the fashion shoe company reported second quarter net income fell 70 percent versus a year ago and Morgan Stanley lowered its rating on the shares to neutral.
The S&P 500 index fell 7.15 points to 947.14.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.52 to a record 1594.33.
